column1: Intellectual property (IP) refers to creations of the intellect for which a monopoly is assigned to designated owners by law. Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are the protections granted to the creators of IP
column6: and in some jurisdictions trade secrets. Artistic works including music and literature
column12: and designs can all be protected as intellectual property.While intellectual property law has evolved over centuries
column13: it was not until the 19th century that the term intellectual property began to be used
column14: and not until the late 20th century that it became commonplace in the majority of the world.The Statute of Monopolies (1624) and the British Statute of Anne (1710) are seen as the origins of patent law and copyright respectively
column15: firmly establishing the concept of intellectual property.
